bio: Poland’s first multi-time world champion and now a five-time winner of the Speedway GP World Championship, Bartosz Zmarzlik is making a career out of rewriting the history books. Zmarzlik was schooled at his local club Gorzow, racing with Polish great Tomasz Gollob in his early years. But the pupil is now the master. Since joining the series full-time for 2016, Bartek has amassed an astonishing eight FIM Speedway World Championship medals in nine years, winning gold in 2019, 2020, 2022, 2023 and 2024, silver in 2018 and 2021 and bronze in 2016. He won an incredible five rounds from the nine he raced in 2023 and sealed gold with an unforgettable win at Torun's Marian Rose Motoarena - a victory that saw him match Aussie legend Jason Crump's all-time series record of 23 wins. He smashed that record with victory at the 3P Logistics FIM Speedway GP of Sweden - Malilla on June 15, before extending it with wins in Riga and Torun in the closing rounds of 2024. Zmarzlik cemented his spot among the sport's greats by sealing his fifth Speedway GP world title in Vojens on September 14 - becoming only the second rider in history after New Zealand legend Ivan Mauger to win gold three years in a row. He bids to match Mauger and Swedish great Tony Rickardsson's all-time record haul of six world titles in 2025.

Great Britain hero Robert Lambert has enjoyed a rapid rise in recent years. After winning the 2020 Speedway European Championship to qualify for Speedway GP, he ended his country’s 32-year wait for a world team title at the 2021 FIM Speedway of Nations Final in Manchester. Norfolk's finest made it two FIM Speedway of Nations world titles in three years in Manchester on July 13, 2024, before storming to his first-ever Speedway GP victory at the Deluxe Homeart FIM Speedway GP of Denmark - Vojens on September 14 to guarantee his place on the Speedway GP World Championship podium. He then saw off Swedish rival Fredrik Lindgren to seal silver on a tense night at the final round in Torun. After becoming only the third Brit to win a medal in the Speedway GP era, following former world champions Mark Loram and Tai Woffinden, the new world No.2 goes for gold in the 2025 Speedway GP series.

Sweden’s Fredrik Lindgren has cemented his position as his country’s top rider since returning to the World Championship full-time in 2017 – culminating in his surge to the Speedway GP silver medal in 2023. The double Swedish champion has also stormed to three Speedway GP bronze medals in 2018, 2020 and 2024 to establish himself as a regular world-title contender and defied a battle with long Covid to remain in the world's top five every season since 2018. Lindgren has scored more Speedway GP World Championship points, made more Speedway GP appearances and raced more Speedway GP heats than any other member of the line-up. He is also now Speedway GP's all-time top-scoring Swede.

Great Britain hero Dan Bewley wrote his name in British speedway folklore when he ended the nation's 15-year wait for an FIM Speedway GP of Great Britain – Cardiff winner on August 13, 2022. The big results just kept on coming as he won the 2022 FIM Speedway GP of Poland – Wroclaw on his PGE Ekstraliga home track just two weeks later, before adding 2023 FIM Speedway GP of Sweden - Malilla gold to his trophy haul. Bewley wrote his name in GB history when he helped the Lions to FIM Speedway of Nations world-title gold in Manchester in October 2021 – their first world team title since 1989. He made it two world team titles in three years for GB at the 2024 FIM Speedway of Nations - also staged on his British home track in Manchester on July 13. Victory at the 2024 FIM Speedway GP of Great Britain - Cardiff, which saw him lead an historic one-two with Robert Lambert, sparked his late-season surge to a career-best fourth place in the Speedway GP World Championship. Can he win his first medal in 2025?

Slovakia’s first and only FIM Speedway Grand Prix star, Martin Vaculik became the nation's first FIM Speedway World Championship medallist when he bagged bronze in 2023. His success on the world stage saw him awarded Slovakia’s prestigious Crystal Wing in March 2024 – a prize that honours heroes from every walk of life in his homeland. Vaculik made an unforgettable World Championship debut, when he won the 2012 FIM Gorzow Speedway GP after replacing the injured Jaroslaw Hampel in the meeting. He ended 2024 a nine-time Speedway GP winner after racing to his third straight FIM Speedway GP of Czech Republic – Prague victory in his adopted home event, as well as topping the podium in Wroclaw on his way to fifth place in the 2024 Speedway GP World Championship. Can Vaculik add Speedway GP World Championship gold to his CV in 2025?

Aussie ace Jack Holder was handed an unexpected Speedway GP debut season in 2022 following the suspension of Artem Laguta and Emil Sayfutdinov. It was a chance he grasped with both hands as he starred for his country in the 2022 FIM Speedway of Nations Final at Vojens, helping the Roos land their first world team title since 2002. Holder then stormed to a fantastic fourth place in the 2023 Speedway GP series, beaten to bronze by only two points. Having missed 2023 round seven in Riga due to a broken wrist, it's very likely Holder's crash at the Monster Energy FIM Speedway World Cup Final in Wroclaw weeks earlier cost him a place on the podium in a year he reached five SGP rostrums. Holder has long been a regular visitor to Speedway GP events, after supporting older brother Chris in the pits for many years. But now the world No.6 has taken the spotlight in his own right and he opened his 2024 season by claiming his first Speedway GP win in Croatia. This saw the Holder brothers make history as the first sibling duo to both win an SGP round, before the younger sibling ended the year with automatic qualification for 2025.

Danish star Mikkel Michelsen picked up his first-ever Speedway GP victory in Landshut in 2024, having qualified for the series by racing to his third Speedway European Championship in 2023. With Michelsen also reaching finals in Gorzow and Wroclaw, he was firmly in the hunt for a 2024 Speedway GP World Championship medal - until his campaign was ended by multiple injuries suffered at the OlyBet FIM Speedway GP of Latvia - Riga on September 7. Michelsen's absence saw him slip from fourth to seventh in the final standings, missing out on automatic qualification. But he is back for 2025 after receiving a permanent wild card from the SGP Commission. Can he mount a podium push in 2025?

Poland's Dominik Kubera was hotly-tipped as a future Speedway GP star - and that dream became a reality in 2024 after he received a permanent wild card from the SGP Commission. A graduate of the Leszno academy, Kubera burst on to the Speedway GP stage as wild card for the 2021 FIM Lublin Speedway GP double-header, reaching back-to-back finals, finishing second on night one and third on night two, as well as reaching the FIM Swedish Speedway GP semis that year. Kubera raced to 2023 Monster Energy FIM Speedway World Cup gold with Poland in Wroclaw on July 29. He finished eighth in his debut Speedway GP season in 2024 - taking fourth place in the Landshut, Prague and Cardiff rounds along the way. Third place at the 2024 FIM SGP Challenge in Pardubice secured Kubera's return to the Speedway GP series for 2025.

Latvia's first-ever Speedway GP rider, Andzejs Lebedevs made his full-time World Championship debut in 2024 after receiving a permanent wild card from the SGP Commission. The Daugavpils-born racer won the 2017 Speedway European Championship, before taking his country to new heights by leading them into the 2021 FIM Speedway of Nations Final in Manchester. He repeated that feat by taking them to a second FIM SON Final at Britain's National Speedway Stadium in 2024. Despite a difficult start to his SGP season in 2024, Lebedevs raced into form, becoming Latvia's first-ever Speedway GP finalist in Vojens on September 14. He then secured his spot in the 2025 Speedway GP series a week later by winning his second Speedway European Championship in Chorzow on September 21. Now Latvia's Speedway GP pioneer bids to take his career to another level.

Max Fricke inked his name in Australian racing history when he helped his country to 2022 FIM Speedway of Nations gold; their first world team title since 2002. That wasn't his only golden moment of 2022 as he also topped the podium at the Orlen FIM Speedway GP of Poland - Warsaw in front of over 50,000 fans at PGE Narodowy. The 2016 FIM Speedway Under-21 world champion made his Speedway GP debut in 2020. The season was a baptism of fire, but Fricke still fought his way to a solid 10th place, claiming his first-ever win at FIM Torun Speedway GP round seven. Fricke built on that by finishing a career-best eighth in 2021, before finishing 13th in the 2022 series. Despite a better year in 2023, taking ninth spot and reaching six semi-finals in 10 rounds, Fricke was forced to make do with a first reserve spot for 2024. He still featured in eight rounds, finishing 11th in the standings, before securing an instant Speedway GP return for 2025 with fourth place at the 2024 FIM SGP Challenge in Pardubice.

German racer Kai Huckenbeck became his country's first full-time Speedway GP rider for 10 years when he lined up in the 2024 series. Following in the footsteps of 2014 FIM New Zealand Speedway GP winner Martin Smolinski, Huckenbeck took on the best in the world after scoring 11 points from three SGP appearances in 2023. After receiving a Speedway GP wild card from the SGP Commission, he raced to 12th place in the Speedway GP World Championship in 2024, reaching three semi-finals along the way, as well as leading Germany to an historic fourth place at the 2024 FIM Speedway of Nations Final in Manchester on July 13 - the country's best result of the 21st century. He gets the chance to build on that campaign after receiving another permanent wild card from the SGP Commission for 2025.

Czech charger Jan Kvech became his country's first full-time Speedway GP rider since Lukas Dryml raced in the 2008 series after finishing fifth in the 2023 FIM SGP Challenge in Gislaved, Sweden. While only the top three riders were guaranteed qualification for 2024, second-placed Slovak star Martin Vaculik went on to win Speedway GP bronze – meaning he qualified automatically and did not need the spot he earned at the Challenge. With fourth-placed Robert Lambert also sealing a top-six finish, Kvech was promoted into Speedway GP. The 2023 second substitute rider has emerged as one of his country's key performers on the world stage. And the 2022 FIM SGP2 and SON2 silver medallist ended a testing 2024 season on a high by reaching his first Speedway GP semi-final in Torun on September 28 - weeks after lifting his first Czech Championship in Pilsen. He gets the chance to build on a fine finish to 2024 after receiving another permanent wild card from the SGP Commission for 2025.

After years doubling up between Britain’s top two leagues, Jason Doyle made his FIM Speedway Grand Prix debut in 2015. The Aussie quickly made himself at home and launched a breathtaking title charge in 2016. Despite winning four Speedway GP rounds, Doyle’s championship dreams were cruelly dashed when he crashed out of the penultimate round in Torun. But he hit back in epic style in 2017. Racing most of the season with a broken foot couldn’t stop Speedway GP’s man of steel, who stormed to an unforgettable world-title win, sealing gold in front of an ecstatic home crowd in Melbourne – winning the FIM Australian Speedway GP too for good measure. He started the 2024 season in breathtaking style, taking second spot at the opener in Croatia, before topping the podium in front of around 50,000 fans at the Orlen FIM Speedway GP of Poland - Warsaw to end six and a half years without an SGP win. Sadly his campaign was cut short after he suffered a torn rotator cuff in a crash in a British Premiership match in King's Lynn last May. Fortunately for Doyle, a permanent wild card from the SGP Commission ensures he can bounce back in 2025.

Triple Danish champion Anders Thomsen is back on the Speedway GP stage for 2025 after a year's break, and he returns in red-hot form. His progress was slowed by injuries that ended both his 2022 and 2023 seasons early, with Thomsen losing his spot in Speedway GP at the end of 2023. But he bounced back in fine style in 2024, winning his third Danish Championship and racing into the top 10 in Poland's PGE Ekstraliga averages for Stal Gorzow. Thomsen crowned a strong season by finishing second at the 2024 FIM SGP Challenge in Pardubice to secure an immediate return to Speedway GP for 2025.

Winner of the 2024 FIM SGP Challenge in Pardubice, Aussie racer Brady Kurtz blazes on to the Speedway GP stage for the first time in 2025. Kurtz's rise began when he won the Australian Championship at the very first attempt in 2016, before establishing himself as one of the country's top stars competing in Europe. After racing for his country in the 2016 FIM Speedway World Cup, he returned to the national side with an inspirational performance as the Roos won 2024 FIM Speedway of Nations silver in Manchester. Two league title wins in three years with British giants Belle Vue in 2022 and 2024 and a Metalkas 2. Ekstraliga victory with Rybnik in 2024 send Kurtz into Speedway GP on a high, along with his second Australian Championship win in January 2025. How will he fare against the sport's elite this year?
